content.webTitle: Championship roundup: Bolton Wanderers make it five wins out of five

fields.headline: Championship roundup: Bolton Wanderers make it five wins out of five
fields.bodyText: Bolton Wanderers 1-0 Brighton & Hove Albion Gus Poyet said he would wait to review the evidence before confronting Ashley Barnes over his late red card, when the Brighton player appeared to make contact with referee Nigel Miller off the ball. "I cannot confirm what happened because I haven't talked to him yet. I was looking at the ball. I need to see the incident on DVD, so let's wait. It is difficult to give an opinion when you don't know what happened." Dougie Freedman paid tribute to his left-back Marcos Alonso after his winning goal made it five wins from as many matches for Bolton, and eight games unbeaten. "He's the kind of guy who plays with a desperation to win at all costs." Leicester City 0-1 Sheffield Wednesday Nigel Pearson has admitted his Leicester side are going through a "crisis of confidence" after they slumped to a fourth defeat in seven games. "I can't fault the players for their efforts, but we were not fluid and didn't solve the problems Wednesday gave us. They came with a solid foundation and things didn't go our way for a number of reasons. But I have a strong belief in these players – we just have to keep our nerve." Dave Jones was delighted to see his side bounce back from Tuesday's defeat against Watford: "It shows you how far we have come as a football club because when we played them in November they were by far the better team." Nottingham Forest 3-1 Wolverhampton Wanderers Billy Davies has warned his Forest players not to get carried away despite a fifth straight win sending them into the play-off zone. "We can take a lot of confidence from getting into the top six, but I spelt out a message to the players afterwards. It is that you can fall out of the top six as quickly as you got into it, so I am stressing the need to focus on every one of our remaining nine games." Two goals by Henri Lansbury, who has now scored four in six games, made the difference against a Wolves side that at times looked capable of springing a surprise. Dean Saunders said: "We were in the game for a long time and deserved at least a point. I'm not going to get down in the dumps." And the rest Birmingham manager Lee Clark praised game-changing subs Wes Thomas and Nathan Redmond for inspiring their side to a 3-1 home win against Derby. "I decided to get the two lads on with a bit of power and pace. I am delighted for both of them." ■ Charlton's manager Chris Powell was delighted with Callum Harriott after the teenager scored the only goal of the game away at Huddersfield. "He's a talent. He did exceptionally well for the goal and worked hard for the team. We have high hopes for him." ■ And Peterborough goalkeeper Bobby Olejnik won his manager Darren Ferguson's praise for his performance against Ipswich – the club's first goalless draw for 172 matches. "Bobby produces two brilliant saves."
